message.content:
cs.CR, cs.GT, cs.SY, cs.AI, cs.NI 

This paper deals with the security challenges posed by Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) in critical infrastructure networks. It proposes a game-theoretic framework to capture the incomplete information of deceptive APTs and their multi-stage movement. The paper also discusses the use of Bayesian Nash equilibrium (BNE) to predict attacker's behaviors and design defensive strategies. Therefore, the most likely arXiv CS sub-category for this paper is cs.CR (Cryptography and Security). 

The paper also uses game theory to model the interactions between the attacker and defender, which suggests that it could also belong to the cs.GT (Computer Science and Game Theory) sub-category. 

Moreover, the paper discusses the use of dynamic programming to compute the equilibrium solution, which suggests that it could also belong to the cs.SY (Systems and Control) sub-category. 

The paper also discusses the use of Bayesian methods to update the belief of the defender, which suggests that it could also belong to the cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) sub-category. 

Finally, the paper deals with the security challenges in critical infrastructure networks, which suggests that it could also belong to the cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture) sub-category.
